description: From Middle French adapter, from Latin adaptāre (“to fit to”), from ad- (“to”) + aptāre (“to make fit”), from aptus (“fit”); see apt.

adjectives.description: adapt (comparative more adapt, superlative most adapt)

examples: This prediction, though somewhat obscure, is wonderfully adapt.

verbs.description: adapt (third-person singular simple present adapts, present participle adapting, simple past and past participle adapted)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To make suitable; to make to correspond; to fit or suit
(transitive) To fit by alteration; to modify or remodel for a different purpose; to adjust
examples: to adapt a story for the stage
to adapt an old machine to a new manufacture

entries.meaning: (transitive) To make by altering or fitting something else; to produce by change of form or character
examples: to bring out a play adapted from the French
a word of an adapted form

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To make oneself comfortable to a new thing.
examples: They could not adapt to the new climate and so perished.
